text: Buongiorno a tutti. I am looking for some recommendations/advice. I am planning on going to visit family in Asiago, Italy in late November/early December. The closest airports to Asiago are Bologna, Verona, Venice or Milan. We are not planning on renting a car and will be travelling by train or bus from the airport to Asiago. I am looking for suggestions as to which is the best route to Asiago, that has some nice points of interest to stop along the way, between the airport we land in and Asiago. Thanks for your time.

comments.comment_text: Check rome to Rio app from all those cities. It will show all.of your options

The best route to Asiago from the four airports you mentioned depends on your interests and budget. Here are a few options:

Bologna: This is the closest airport to Asiago, and it is also the most affordable option. You can take a train from Bologna Centrale station to Asiago. The journey takes about 2 hours.

Verona: This airport is a bit further from Asiago than Bologna, but it has more flight options. You can take a train from Verona Porta Nuova station to Asiago. The journey takes about 2.5 hours.

Venice: This airport is the furthest from Asiago, but it is also the most popular tourist destination in Italy. You can take a train from Venice Santa Lucia station to Asiago. The journey takes about 3 hours.

Milan: This airport is also a popular tourist destination, but it is not as close to Asiago as Bologna or Verona. You can take a train from Milan Centrale station to Asiago. The journey takes about 3.5 hours.

If you are looking for a route with some nice points of interest to stop along the way, I would recommend flying into Bologna and taking the train to Asiago. You can stop in the town of Vicenza, which is known for its beautiful architecture.

You can also stop in the town of Marostica, which is known for its annual chess tournament that is played in the streets.

If you are flying into Verona, you can stop in the town of Verona, which is home to the famous Verona Arena.

If you are flying into Venice, you can stop in the city of Venice itself, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

I’m so sorry this happened to you. I can imagine how disappointed you are.

But as someone who was involved in a life threatening accident in Rome that required hospitalization
and surgery I have to say I’m glad his problem
happened here instead of in Italy. To be honest, I received excellent medical care there and they saved my life. But it’s very frightening and psychologically
difficult to deal with a medical system you’re unfamiliar with. And where you maybe aren’t fluent with the language. (I can say some common phrases in Italian but medical terms were beyond me.). Then there’s the financial aspect. Before leaving the first hospital I had to pay 24 thousand Euros for my stay of three days plus surgery. The second hospitalization
which lasted two full weeks was additional. I can’t even begin to tell you how stressful it would have been to face those worries in a foreign country on top of concerns for your sons health.

On the bright side, as I said before, I was treated very well by the doctors and hospital staff. All of my hotels were extremely cooperative and refunded my non refundable payments in full. I hadn’t expected that but was certainly happy they did it. I had purchased flight insurance which covered my missed flight back home. I was also lucky in that my home medical insurance reimbursed me in full for the amount I had to pay the Italian hospitals. And my insurance also paid for a first class flight ticket to get me home as well as paid for a nurse to accompany me.

So although you were unlucky with what happened, in another way you were lucky it happened before your trip not while you were on it.

Here’s what I learned from my own experience.
1. Buy medical insurance for each trip. Most US policies do not provide for the reimbursement mine did. But you do need to have coverage while abroad.
2. Buy flight insurance. It’s cheap
but so important if something happens.
3. Be sure any insurance you have provides for evacuation home.
4. Always book directly with the provider (the airline or the hotel itself, for example) because the third party is just another layer of bureaucracy you have to deal with if something goes wrong.
5. Stay in a fully staffed hotel not a vacation rental. The help provided by the hotel staff was invaluable to me. From going with me in an ambulance, to making arrangements to extend my husband’s longer than intended stay at reduced rates, to making phone calls for us I honestly can’t imagine how we’d have navigated the situation without their kindness and help. They did so many things, both little and big, to help
us out during our nightmare. I’ll be forever grateful to all of them.
6. Take along an extra high limit credit card to be used only in case of an emergency.

None of this will help you right now. But I wanted you to know you’re not alone in having had a trip ruined by medical issues. I’m proof that anything can happen so I hope passing on what I learned might somehow help to prevent struggles in the future.

And of course, I hope your son is fine and healthy now. That’s really the most important thing.

We just returned from an amazing trip to Italy and wanted to share some of the highlights as you were all so helpful to us! If you need additional info, please do not hesitate to ask. We flew round trip, Boston to Rome and on arrival day took a connecting flight with ITA Airways to Venice. Our itinerary was: 2 nights Venice, 3 nights Ortisei (Dolomites), 3 nights Florence, 2 nights Chianti and 4 nights Rome. 2 nights in Venice: 1. Stayed at Corte de Gabriela (lovely boutique hotel with a charming courtyard, great location, wonderful and attentive staff.) 2. Viator tour of St. Mark’s and Doge’s Palace – Walks of Italy - excellent tour guide. 3. Day trip to Burano using the public water taxi. Loved it. 4. Drinks at Pitti Palace right on the Grand Canal – what a treat! We loved Venice – there is a surprise waiting at every turn! Departure day: Trenitalia from Venice to Bolzano via Verona, with round trip car service from Bolzano to our Hotel. 3 nights in Ortisei – in the Western Dolomites. This is a very beautiful village, with access to spectacular hikes and stunning views. 1. Stayed at the Hotel Gardena Grodnerhof (exceptional hotel, our favorite of the trip. Customer Service really excels here! Breakfast is phenomenal; you would not believe the selection. The bar area is incredible. Delicious dinners too!) 2. Hiked the Seceda trails. 3. Hiked Alpe de Suissi. Very sad to leave! Departure day: Trenitalia from Bolzano to Firenze. Give yourselves ample time with train connections (we had 20 min). The train from Bolzano to Bologna was delayed so we missed our connection to Firenze. Scrambled to find another option. Luckily, we had downloaded the ITALO app and were able to get seats on that train as Trenitalia was sold out for the rest of the day! 3 nights in Florence: 1. Stayed at Hotel Spadai (great location and icy cold AC but for me, it fell short in other ways, just felt too boxed in. Most rooms in cities are smaller but something about the layout here and breakfast on the highest floor (with little to no ac). It was just ok for me. Hotel staff, nice. 2. Viator tour of Accademia (incl David) and climb of the Duomo Cupola was great. 3. With Passepartout, visited the Uffizi Gallery, Pitti Palace and Boboli Gardens. The latter two were ok in comparison to the Uffizi, one of the most amazing art galleries we have visited, ever. 4. Ate lunch one day at the Mercato Centrale – upstairs. Everything was so delicious. 5. Piazza della Signoria – stunning, especially at night. 6. Piazza della Republicca, love the cafes there. This is also a stunning piazza. 7. Piazzale Michelangelo – challenging walk up, but well worth the view of Firenze. 8. Ponte Vecchio – it’s all jewelry stores but beautiful. Departure day: round trip car service from Firenze to Castellina in Chianti. 2 nights in Castellina in Chianti: 1. We stayed at Castello La Leccia, a gem, with breathtaking views of the countryside from this winery/agriturismo on a hill. Truly a special place and a close second to Gardena Gardenerhof. 2. Beautiful pool which we enjoyed on arrival day. 3. Private tour with Corrado di Pompeo with Tourscany. He was wonderful. His goal is to ensure that you have a great experience. With Corrado, we visited in one day: Siena (gorgeous), San Gimignano (also gorgeous with the most delicious gelato at Dondoli), and Monteriggioni (smaller and beautiful). We also visited two wineries, including Poggio Amorelli, where we had a delicious lunch and wine tasting. Departure day: Trenitalia from Florence to Rome, with car pick up at train station. 4 nights in Rome: Stayed at the Hotel Locarno – lovely, trendy boutique hotel near Piazza del Popolo. 10-minute walk to Piazza di Spagna but about 20-25 min to most other places. This was just fine for us, given that the food in Rome was spectacular! 2. Liv Tour of Vatican Museums, Sistene Chapel and St Peter’s Basilica. 3. Liv Tour of Colosseum and Roman Forum. 3. Visited Fontana di Trevi, Piazza Navona, Campo de Fiori, and the Pantheon. 4. Visited the Cappuccini Crypts. 5. Visited the Borghese Gardens. 6. Visited Trastevere twice for dinner. Rome was our favorite city. It is lively and offers jaw dropping historical sites, beautiful churches, delicious food, and warm and gracious people. Admittedly, we tossed farewell coins into the Trevi Fountain, hoping to return someday soon. Safe and happy travels to all!

Hi everyone 👋
I would love to get some advise/ opinions please 🙏.
My husband & I will visiting Italy in mid September & super excited. Just wondering what the crowds will be like in regards to catching trains. I see a lot of stories on tick tok & other platforms & the crowds are horrendous 😳
Will this be the case come mid Sept? What are people’s experience with public transport in particular train transportation?

comments.comment_text: We love traveling by train in Italy. I buy tickets in advance with assigned seats so we can choose where on the train we will be.

Thus depends on what kind of trains you are talking about. We travel in the Tuscany region on regional trains. Only trains that are busy are the ones heading to Florence and then by busy I'm not saying there is no room. When qe go between small towns like Siena or Orvieto from Sinalunga we may be the only people in our section. Kids sometimes going to school. Maybe 10. As far as big cites like Rome or Naples, yes it is crowded. If you are able to go in May or October it's better. We stick to Tuscany and Umbria regions and take the lovely completely stress free local trains. We have even helped Italian tourists when they are questioning if they are on the right bin or tract.
I think you will be fine. Just book in advance.
I thinky you will be fine . Just book in advance.
There's a rail strike planned for mid-September for one day. It's scheduled for 3:00 AM on Sept 17 to 2:00 AM Sept 18. We are traveling on the 18th but at 8:30 AM. It's the Italo lines.
You will be fine. Get to the station about 30 mins before the train is due, then when the platform is announces on the board go straight to the platform.... You will be fine.

If you are on regional trains like the ones we use you buy your tickets from a kiosk. No announcements of any kind, not even in SMN train station ( Florence ). Just a scrolling electronic board that posts your bin about 30 minutes before the train arrives. You can buy tickets in small towns from tabacco shops if they are open. I'm posting this because not everyone takes high speed trains with classes. There are no designated 1st or 2nd. All the same.

Many times we have experienced trains and buses in Italy. People tend to cram themselves on board both- shoulder to shoulder so watch your belongings. However, on trains, if you are able to make a reservation (some local trains you can’t), you will have a seat. Be sure to arrive at the station early, go to the track as soon as you know the number and stand and be assertive about boarding! Also, note that some tracks are quite a hike from the main terminal, especially with the local trains so know where you are going in the station and give yourself plenty of time.

I booked most of our trains in advance. A few had assigned seats, others did not. It was intimidating at first, but gets easier. Just watch the boards. This was an EXCELLENT video we watched beforehand. Clarified a lot and made the experience more smooth.
https://
youtu.be/
0KSKiVjng8o

How can anyone know what is going to happen mid September? Travel is at an all time high this year. Summer is always the worst. Hopefully the crowds of summer will lessen. Just plan accordingly. We are taking a train September 8th from Florence to Rome and booked ahead.

It shouldn't be too bad in September, the holidays are over and most locals are back to work and school. There are also a lot less foreign tourists about, specially down here in the south. A perfect time to visit actually.

We have taken trains all over Western Europe, including Italy. It can be crowded at the larger stations even during "shoulder season" and people can be rude, but it always works out. Travel light (long platforms, steps into coaches). Smaller / older stations may not have elevator or even working escalator. It's a wonderful way to travel. Book in advance, select your seat to have a full window and be forward facing.
